comments.commentBody: Trump has told so many lies, I am surprised when he does tell the truth.   Some trust him, but we must have verification before taking it to the bank.

Several years ago, while living in North Carolina, a Southerner and friend told me that "Southerners has such a high regard for the truth that they use it sparingly". I was amused, but I've never forgotten that - whether it is Bill Clinton parsing out his words regarding Lewinsky, or Sessions on this matter.

Under no circumstances should we let up on this. If it's no biggie, then why do they lie about it every single day? If this were a Democratic administration Republicans would be setting puppies on fire on live TV.
Some times in a witch hunt you find a witch.  Trump, maybe you find some honesty.
That's some stretchin' Thelma.  Let's hold hands, I'll be Louise.

Is it "dangerous and distracting" to thoroughly investigate an attempt of a foreign government to subvert our institutions? The subversion is clearly apparent, as it is also clear that the Russian effort was abetted by Trump when he praised the leaks and called for more illegally hacked information. Neither he nor any of his surrogates condemned these subversive acts. It is also clear that the hacking operation is part of a Russian plan to destabilize democratic governments in Europe and elsewhere. Who could have ever imagined a Republican party, who for decades told us that the Russians were coming, to remain so mute about this threat? Instead they are acting so as to distract us from the threat.
We need a special prosecutor appointed immediately with the legal power to compel testimony.

I would assume that the international community of Western Europe, Japan,  and others would have their own concerns about the integrity of this administration as well as the connection of Russian interference in the elections of very powerful nations.  It is another way to isolate the US from its allies.  It has already been reported that Western European nations have shared intelligence on this issue with the Obama administration.  To maintain or regain our integrity, and the integrity of the elections of the most democratic republic on Earth we can not just close our eyes and jump down the rabbit hole.

Ummmm. Treacherous people in and around Mr. T's team have of course alternate truths. Jeff S. as a natural person met the guy from Mr. P's state. As a senator, Jeff met the guy. But as a campaign operative Jeff did not communicate with the guy. Jeff chose to talk about the last truth.

Al Franken (my fading memory remembers him in SNL many years ago) was asking seriously about what Jeff would do, if it turns out Mr. T's campaign team members had met with the guy from Russia (this is a short version and misses details and nuances). Of course, Jeff did not answer that question and talked about his chosen favored truth about himself. He is not stupid.

This pattern of avoidance and projecting impression based on preferable alternate truth should not be news to you, Dear Reasonable Americans. I remember Kellyanne Conway is like this. Is she still holding onto her job at the White House?

I find it heavily ironic that a man who protested neither Tea Party Demonstrations nor then candidate Trump’s encouraging his followers to violence, now wants to ignore the Constitutional Right to Assembly when it comes to those who disagree with him. And so, I pose to Governor Walker the same question once posed to a Senator from Wisconsin, “At long last, have you left no sense of decency?”

Gov. Walker, have you any objections to secession, a version of states rights, right?

As for me, my position is about 180 degrees off yours but i wonder if we would agree that everything might work out smoothly with "extended states rights."

Sometimes divorce is a good thing. Now, why would you object to that? No, really. I'm curious.

Seems this idea of protesting one's election loss changes the outcome has become a movement.  Just because a loser protests the winner doesn't mean the loser's vote should have a mulligan.   If the protesters were the ones who voted for the winner, they should not be ignored.  But that is not the case here, all the protesters are the voters who voted for the loser, and they don't get a do over.  Representatives do well to not act on protests from the losers.

Eric, will you please, please tell me how to get in touch with the rent-a-mob people? I would absolutely love to do that protesting stuff AND get paid for it. A dream come true for this old duffer. Please, please, tell me how to do it. Send it in code, so I can figure it out without a whole bunch of other people ruining it. I can even give you my email address. Code it up. I will bust the code. Thank you in advance.

Charles

" the most workable compromise"

No, it is not a most workable compromise. A lot of countries like Italy, Germany, India and France limit elective abortion to three months of pregnancy.

The Supreme Court, by CREATING a constitutional right to abortion for six months, three months beyond the countries I mentioned, has created something which is inhuman, and objected to even by many pro-choicers.

Sure, reproductive rights. But they must be balanced with the other half of the equation that every abortion takes a human life.

Our Senator Collins also only meets privately with pre-screened constituents.  no town hall meeting for her.  "private meetings are more effective".  Don't be fooled by her sudden independence... just show.

Don't forget Kansas, where Governor Brownback is the most unpopular governor in the country and Republican control of state government means that the state does not adequately fund education in any form for its residents' children.  Instead, buy lowering taxes--the only thing which matters to Republicans--they have incurred a billion-dollar-plus state debt and no way to pay it off.

Mr. Walker's ultimate aim is a confederacy, as is that of the entire GOP. The thought experiment: 50 loose-coupled nation states. Each with impermeable borders; papers required - all unique, and the notion of comity left to the discretion of the border patrol. The jurisdiction of the three branches of government - now naught but twigs - limited to the national defense, with years of Commerce Clause and Bill of Rights (especially that pesky 14th Amendment!) SCOTUS decisions reversed because their foundation has been compromised.

Start hoarding.
I thought we defeated that idea during the Civil War, but I think you are fight . Abraham Lincoln will be turning over in his grave

Mr Walker you need to read history before the Great Depression and see what a great job the States and Governors did taking care of people in the States.  There was nothing to fall back on in hard times but family and without that the soup lines formed and the poor houses were built to give families shelter.  They were called "poor farms" and there were worse than their name.  If you were sick -- tough luck -- you died.  Thank goddess for FDR who had the sense to see what needed to be done and saved our country.  No one will ever say that about you.

After reading Gov. Walker's comments, I am more fearful than ever (for the future of our country).

While he does not include total lies in his commentary, his shading of the truth is remarkable.

When will our nation's voters come to their senses and kick the Walkers to the curb?

I judge any political party or representative on their actions not on what they say so I can ignore even this self-serving screed from Walker. Actions speak louder than words. From the actions of the Republicans over the last 40 or so years it is quite clear that their ultimate desire -- their hearts' fondest dream -- is a lower standard of living for the average American.

Until recently Republicans tried to hide this desire because it's pretty hard to sell a lower standard of living to those whose lives are going to be negatively impacted by that standard. Walker was among the first of them who decided that it is acceptable to stop hiding that desire and bring it out into the open. I can only conclude that he and the rest of the Republicans now believe that so many Americans are so stupid that they will fall for claptrap like this article.

The sad fact is that they are succeeding. How? Are Americans really so stupid that they can't look back at history and see that Republicans have not proposed a single initiative over the last several decades that would have benefited the non-rich American?

No wonder Republicans fight education and love the uneducated so much. Ignorance benefits them immensely.

I'm old enough to remember when there were Republicans who didn't view Americans as just Soylent Green for business and the rich. Today's Republican party offers us only Walkers who want us to be poorer, sicker, and more desperate. What in the world happened to my country?
Well said!

Words fail me . My daughter lives in Madison where there is a reign of terror against one of the finest universities in the world. One of the many reasons it was so good was arrangements to share in the profits of patents (Warfarin- Coumadin was named after Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation) . Another was that the mission was pursuit of truth-- until Gov walker preferred employment to truth . A third was the excellent hospital medical school and VA all in the downtown of medium sized city , along with the law school, the vet school, the undergrad school. Now young researchers are leaving and established researchers need to prove to the state they work more the 3 hours a week-- check out when the lights are on the chemistry building, or the basement of the vet school , Gov Walker .

Maybe in 10 years when all the bright young Wisconsinites have moved away for an education , and they don't return because there is nothing for them and their families you can turn that useless old campus into a nursing home .
Really an excellent suggestion. The states, so easily gerrymandered, now serve as institutional barriers to the democratic republic. They are an artifact no longer needed and should be pruned.

As a resident of Wisconsin, I would suggest people take a good hard look at Mr Walker's legacy and then decide on his credibility. We have record deficits, tax give-aways to the wealthy and to corporations that come at the expense of healthcare and education. He has generated an "us against them" mentality in this state that USED to be known for it's civility.  His approval ratings have suffered since his abysmal attempt to capture the GOP nomination and now he is attempting to resurrect his image as Mr Conservative through cheap App-eds and throwing a few bucks at Education in WI. In short, he's a third rate political hack with big dollar backers controlling his every move. Maybe he should take a look at the Democratic governor of Minnesota - that state is in a lot better shape than Wisconsin.

Those (mostly red states) who vociferously argue for "States Rights) would not be too happy to receive in their block grants only an amount equivalent to the federal taxes they pay in. No more subsidizing of poor red states by better off blue states - let's see how they like that.

I'll make a "positive argument" that Gov. Scott Walker is free to repeat:

I'm positive that Gov. Walker's policies, if fully implemented, will result in the deaths of many thousands of people who lose their health insurance, jobs, and social safety net that now protects them.

Should a state have the right to abandon air or water pollution regulations even if that putrid detritus contaminates neighboring states who have understood the value of strict regulations that benefit the health of their citizens? I think not. But this is the concept of our current so-called President and leader of the EPA. All hail the gods of States Rights!
